initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The winner of a prestigious Xiangqi tournament has been deprived of their championship title and faces a year-long ban from competing after allegations of unacceptable behavior. 

The champion, 48-year-old Yan Chenglong, has also been accused of cheating by using a device similar to a private messaging system. 

Although the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) has been unable to prove the cheating claims, the individual has been punished for their inappropriate actions, including a late-night drinking session that resulted in damage to hotel property and public disturbance. 

According to the CXA, after claiming the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament on the Chinese island of Hainan, Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room. He then committed an act of defecation in the hotel bath that caused damage to the property and breached public order and moral standards. 

In response to rumors circulating online suggesting that Yan used anal beads with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals, the CXA stated that it is currently impossible to prove the cheating allegations. 

As punishment for Yan's bad behavior, he has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year. The amount of prize money Yan is forfeiting has not been disclosed, but it is customary for Xiangqi tournaments to offer winners tens of thousands of yuan, equivalent to thousands of dollars, according to AFP.

The champion of a distinguished Xiangqi tournament has had their championship title revoked and will face a year-long suspension from competition following accusations of inappropriate behavior. The 48-year-old winner, Yan Chenglong, has also been accused of using a device akin to a private messaging system to gain an unfair advantage. Despite the Chinese Xiangqi Association's inability to confirm the cheating allegations, the individual has been sanctioned for their misconduct, which included a late-night drinking episode that resulted in damage to hotel property and disruptions to the public. According to the association, after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament on Hainan Island, Yan celebrated with friends in his hotel room before committing an act of vandalism in the bathroom that damaged hotel property and breached public decency standards. Rumors had circulated online claiming Yan used anal beads with wireless transmitters to communicate, but the association stated that they cannot currently prove these allegations. As a result of his bad behavior, Yan has been stripped of his title and banned from competing for a year. The exact amount of forfeited prize money has not been disclosed, but winners of Xiangqi tournaments typically receive tens of thousands of yuan, equivalent to thousands of dollars.

The champion of a prominent Xiangqi tournament has had their title revoked and will serve a year-long suspension due to allegations of misconduct. The 48-year-old winner, Yan Chenglong, is also accused of utilizing a private communication device to gain an unfair advantage in competition. Despite the lack of concrete evidence to confirm these claims, the Chinese Xiangqi Association has taken disciplinary action, finding Yan responsible for a late-night incident involving excessive drinking, damage to hotel property, and disruptions to the public. Additionally, the association has revoked Yan's title of "Xiangqi King" after investigating a reported incident in which he damaged hotel property and breached decency standards in a hotel bathroom. The investigation did not uncover concrete evidence supporting online rumors that Yan used an unorthodox communication device, and as a result of his conduct, he has been banned from competition for a year and forfeited a portion of his prize money.

The winner of a prestigious Xiangqi competition, Yan Chenglong, has had their title stripped and faces a year-long ban due to allegations of wrongdoing. Specifically, Yan is accused of using a private device to gain an unfair edge during the tournament, as well as engaging in misconduct during the event, including excessive drinking, damaging hotel property, and disturbing others. While evidence supporting these claims is lacking, the Chinese Xiangqi Association has decided to discipline Yan, finding him responsible for his actions. As a result, he has lost his "Xiangqi King" title, been banned from competition for a year, and had to forfeit part of his winnings.

Despite the lack of concrete evidence, the Chinese Xiangqi Association has found Yan accountable for his actions and as a result, he has lost his title, is banned from competing for a year, and has been forced to forfeit part of his winnings.
